Award.AwardTitle: Developing an Electricity-specific Mixed-unit Input-output Model for Life Cycle Assessment and Energy Policy Evaluation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to develop and verify a mixed unit life cycle analysis model of the US electric industry that includes environmental effects and the relationships to many major industries. The model will include both economic and energy/electricity flows. It is anticipated that this model will be a useful tool in energy and environmental policy decisions. Advances in the model will be due to including more interactions with other industries and a disaggregated (i.e. source-specific) power generation sector in the US. The model, if successful, will be an important tool for planners and policy makers.

Bruce K. Hamilton
2/24/10

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to develop an Environmentally-Extended Input-Output (EEIO) model of the U.S. economy that focuses on the power generation and supply (PGS) industry. Input-output models are economic models used to compute the economic requirements needed to produce a given economic output at an economy-wide level. In recent years these models have been paired with environmental data to estimate environmental impacts of economic activity. This project allowed the creation of an EEIO model with the ability to track the physical electricity flows, and the corresponding emissions, in the United States. We incorporated regional economic and environmental data related to different electricity generation technologies, as well electricity trading and consumption between individual states into the model. The finished model allows estimates of economic activity, greenhouse gas emissions, and water consumption for all sectors of the U.S. economy; for power generation and supply, these estimates are available at in physical units, for different types of power generation technologies, and at the state level, features that were not available in previous EEIO models of the U.S. Finally, while the model developed here is focused on the PGS sector, the framework developed is flexible and expandable, such that regional data and physical flows of other sectors of the economy can be added in future work.

The finished model can be used to study different energy policies in the U.S. In this project, we analyzed the environmental effects related to the implementation of Renewable Portfolio Standards (RPS) of individual states vs. a base scenario where these policies are not implemented. The implementation of the RPS does decrease overall greenhouse gas emissions from electricity generation, but there is a tradeoff in the greenhouse gas reduction vs. an increase in water consumption for the new electricity generation capacity added to meet the rising electricity demand and the reduction of more traditional generation technologies, with the extent of the trade-off varying by region. While it is important to note that these projections are not predictions, they give us insights regarding unexpected consequences of applying regional energy policies for reducing greenhouse gas emissions without considering other environmental impacts. These results will hopefully help guide future policy development with regards to electricity production.
